description: From Middle English derk, from Old English deorc, from Proto-West Germanic *derk (“dark”), of uncertain origin, but possibly from Proto-Indo-European *dʰerg- (“dim, dull”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰer- (“dull, dirty”).

definitionGroups.group: Having an absolute or (more often) relative lack of light.

examples: Dark signals should be treated as all-way stop signs.

entries.meaning: Transmitting, reflecting, or receiving inadequate light to render timely discernment or comprehension: caliginous, darkling, dim, gloomy, lightless, sombre.
(of colour) Dull or deeper in hue; not bright or light.
examples: my sister's hair is darker than mine;  her skin grew dark with a suntan

entries.meaning: Ambiguously or unclearly expressed: enigmatic, esoteric, mysterious, obscure, undefined.
Marked by or conducted with secrecy: hidden, secret; clandestine, surreptitious.
examples: (gambling, of race horses) Having racing capability not widely known.

entries.meaning: Without moral or spiritual light; sinister, malign.
examples: a dark villain;  a dark deed

entries.meaning: Conducive to hopelessness; depressing or bleak.
examples: the Great Depression was a dark time;  the film was a dark psychological thriller

entries.meaning: (of a time period) Lacking progress in science or the arts.
examples: The age wherein he lived was dark, but he  Could not want light who taught the world to see.

entries.meaning: Extremely sad, depressing, or somber, typically due to, or marked by, a tragic or undesirable event.
examples: September 11, 2001, the day when four terrorist attacks destroyed the Twin Towers and the Pentagon, is often referred to as America's dark day.

entries.meaning: With emphasis placed on the unpleasant aspects of life; said of a work of fiction, a work of nonfiction presented in narrative form, or a portion of either.
examples: The ending of this book is rather dark.

entries.meaning: (broadcasting, of a television station) Off the air; not transmitting.

description: From Middle English derk, derke, dirke, dyrke, from the adjective (see above), or possibly from an unrecorded Old English *dierce, *diercu (“dark, darkness”).

entries.meaning: A complete or (more often) partial absence of light.

examples: We kept him in the dark.
The lawyer was left in the dark as to why the jury was dismissed.
It was after dark before we got to playing baseball.

entries.meaning: A dark shade or dark passage in a painting, engraving, etc.

description: From Middle English derken, from Old English deorcian, from Proto-West Germanic *derkōn.

verbs.description: dark (third-person singular simple present darks, present participle darking, simple past and past participle darked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To grow or become dark, darken.
(intransitive) To remain in the dark, lurk, lie hidden or concealed.
(transitive) To make dark, darken; to obscure.
